description: Ulam numbers with starting with 1 and 9.
references: C. Pickover, Wonders of Numbers, Oxford University Press, NY, 2001, p. 185-186.
links: C. A. Pickover, "Wonders of Numbers, Adventures in Mathematics, Mind and Meaning," Zentralblatt review
formula: Ulam numbers are positive integers that can be expressed in just one way as the sum of two distinct earlier members of the sequence in increasing order.
example: a(4)=11 is an Ulam number because 10 + 1 = 11, but 19 is not because there is more than one way to form 19 from summing previous sequence numbers, e.g. 18 + 1 and 10 + 9.
author: Jason Earls (zevi_35711(AT)yahoo.com), Mar 16 2001
